key_insight: A neural stochastic differential equation (neural SDE) framework that learns state-dependent drift and diffusion can generatively model single-cell dynamics, producing realistic continuous-time trajectories and enabling in silico perturbation experiments.
problem_solved: How to infer and simulate stochastic, continuous cell-state dynamics (including state-dependent noise) from single-cell data and use those models to predict effects of perturbations in development and disease.
method: Formulate cell dynamics as a neural SDE where both drift and diffusion are parameterized by neural networks that depend on cell state.
Train the generative continuous-time model on single-cell measurements to fit observed trajectories/ distributions, enabling sampling of full stochastic paths in latent or gene-expression space.
Use the learned model to run in silico perturbations and compare trajectories under modified drift/diffusion to study developmental or disease responses.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a principled, flexible way to learn and simulate complex stochastic dynamics from snapshot or time-course single-cell data, improving downstream prediction, interpretation, and virtual perturbation experiments.
visual_elements: Latent-space trajectory plot: observed snapshot points with sampled continuous stochastic paths overlaid
Vector field visualization: learned drift arrows and state-dependent diffusion ellipses across the state space
Perturbation comparison: side-by-side trajectories or distributions for control vs. perturbed model runs
Model schematic: simple block diagram showing input single-cell data → neural SDE (drift & diffusion nets) → generative sampling / perturbation
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
